chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect hypercalcaemia?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Hypercalcaemia is most commonly detected on the basis of blood test results in the UK, and mild chronic hypercalcaemia is usually asymptomatic. Consider a diagnosis of hypercalcaemia if:

  • There is an incidental finding of a corrected serum calcium concentration of 2.6 mmol/L or higher on blood testing.
  • There are suggestive clinical features (which are often non-specific and relate to the severity and rate of onset of hypercalcaemia):
    • Skeletal
      • Bone pain, skeletal deformities.
      • Osteoporosis, fractures associated with underlying bone disorders (fragility fractures in hyperparathyroidism, or pathological fractures in malignancy). See the CKS topic on Osteoporosis - prevention of fragility fractures for more information.
    • Neuromuscular and neuropsychiatric
      • Drowsiness, delirium, coma. See the CKS topic on Delirium for more information.
      • Fatigue, lethargy, muscle weakness, insomnia. See the CKS topics on Tiredness/fatigue in adults and Insomnia for more information.
      • Impaired concentration and memory, confusion. See the CKS topic on Dementia for more information.
      • Depression, anxiety, irritability, psychosis. See the CKS topics on Depression, Generalized anxiety disorder, and Psychosis and schizophrenia for more information.
      • Neurological signs (for example upper motor neurone deficits, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and ataxia).
    • Gastrointestinal
      • Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, weight loss.
      • Constipation, abdominal pain. See the CKS topic on Constipation for more information.
      • Peptic ulcer, pancreatitis (both rare). See the CKS topics on Dyspepsia - proven peptic ulcer and Pancreatitis - acute for more information.
    • Renal
      • Renal colic due to renal stones (nephrolithiasis). See the CKS topic on Renal or ureteric colic - acute for more information.
      • Thirst, polyuria, polydipsia, nocturia, and dehydration (due to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus).
      • Renal impairment (due to nephrocalcinosis and/or obstructive uropathy). See the CKS topic on Chronic kidney disease for more information.
    • Cardiovascular
      • Hypertension. See the CKS topic on Hypertension - not diabetic for more information.
      • Shortened QT interval; prolonged PR interval on electrocardiogram (ECG).
      • Cardiac arrhythmias such as ventricular fibrillation (rare).
    • Other
      • Flushing, itching, band keratopathy (rare). See the CKS topics on Itch - widespread for more information.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect hypercalcaemia are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Hyperparathyroidism (primary): diagnosis, assessment and initial management [NICE, 2019], the international consensus document Guidelines for the management of asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism: Summary statement from the fourth international workshop [Bilezikian et al, 2014], the Society for Endocrinology guideline Emergency management of acute hypercalcaemia in adult patients [Walsh, 2016], and expert opinion in review articles on primary care testing [Smellie et al, 2008], on hypercalcaemia [Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015; Turner, 2017], on parathyroid disorders [Pallan et al, 2012; Michels, 2013; Bilezikian, 2018; Insogna, 2018], on hypercalcaemia of malignancy [Clines, 2011; Zagzag, 2018], and in the palliative care textbook Symptom management in advanced cancer [Twycross et al, 2009].

  • The information that hypercalaemia is most commonly detected incidentally on the basis of blood test results is based on expert opinion in review articles [Pallan et al, 2012; Michels, 2013; Turner, 2017].
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism is typically asymptomatic when it is identified [Meng, 2015; Bilezikian, 2018].
    • In developed countries, about 20% of people with primary hyperparathyroidism present with symptoms, and the remainder are asymptomatic at presentation [Pallan et al, 2012; Insogna, 2018].
  • The information that clinical features of hypercalcaemia may be non-specific and are related to the severity and rate of onset of hypercalcaemia is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2019] and expert opinion in review articles [Clines, 2011; Pallan et al, 2012; Michels, 2013; Meng, 2015; Zagzag, 2018].
    • Intracellular calcium is involved in cell signalling, neural transmission, muscle contraction, enzyme function, hormone secretion, glucogen metabolism, and cell division, and may therefore present with multiple symptoms and signs [Meng, 2015].
    • Malignancy-associated hypercalcaemia is often of rapid onset and presents with symptoms [Clines, 2011; Meng, 2015].
  • The recommendation to consider a diagnosis of hypercalcaemia if there is an incidental finding of a corrected serum calcium concentration of 2.6 mmol/L or higher on blood testing, is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2019].
    • The recommendation to ensure the serum calcium concentration is adjusted ('corrected') for the serum albumin concentration is based on the fact that about 45% of calcium in blood is bound to plasma proteins, particularly albumin. If serum protein concentrations fluctuate, total serum calcium levels may also vary [Smellie et al, 2008; Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015].
